title-group.article-title: The Influence of Geology on Indoor Radon Concentrations in Neelum Valley Azad Kashmir, Pakistan

abstract.p: Geology of parent rock controls strongly the soil properties which in turn effect the generation and transportation of radon from its point of production to the surface of earth’s crust. Indoor radon concentrations mainly depend upon uranium and thorium content beneath the earth surface and diffusion of radon from rock and soil fractures, stoma and fissures. This paper presents the results of a survey of indoor radon concentrations in Neelum Valley District. CR-39 detectors were installed in 210 houses covering the entire study area. The detectors were retrieved after exposing to indoor radon for a period of 90 days and then etched in 6 M NaOH at 80°C for 16 h. The observed track densities were converted into the indoor radon concentrations using calibration factor of 2.7 tracks cm−2·h−1 per kBq·m−3. Mean annual effective doses were calculated for each measured value of radon concentration using UNSCEAR 2000 model. Effects of geology, fissures, crevice and cracks on radon levels have also been discussed. Results obtained from this study have been compared with radon concentration action levels given by the World Health Organisation and US Environmental Protection Agency and UK Health Protection Agency.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In various countries such as the United States, the former Czechoslovakia, France, Canada, Sweden, the United Kingdom and China, several epidemiological studies have been carried out showing the excess occurrence of lung cancer in uranium, fluorspar, metal, iron and tin miners [1–14]. These well-documented studies of underground miners have raised the apprehension that general population living within the closed environments of buildings could also be affected by indoor radon concentrations. Radon and its decay products are invariably present with indoor environments and most of the houses have an indoor radon concentration of about 40 Bq·m−3 [15]. However, some houses could have indoor radon concentrations comparable to that found in underground mines [2]. This suggests that a nearly comparable risk of lung cancer could be associated with radon exposure both in the case of mines and also of houses with high-indoor radon concentrations.

Uranium and Thorium (along with their decay products) ubiquitously distributed in the Earth’s crust in minute amounts within a few metres of ground are directly responsible for the origin of radon. Radon after its formation seeps in to the air present in the soil capillaries, and it is then transported to the atmosphere through the process of diffusion or pressure-induced flow [16]. Within the buildings, radon is trapped in the closed environment resulting in elevated concentrations. Uranium mineralisation (including uraninite, coffinite, tyuyamunite, carnotite, uranophane, autunite and branerite, and that occurs in other minerals, the most common of which are heavy minerals such as titanite, Zircon, allanite and monazite) present within the crust fractures or faults can contribute to higher concentrations of indoor radon [2]. Rock types with uranium concentrations greater than 5 ppm are most likely to cause indoor radon problems including carbonaceous black shales, glauconite-bearing, sand stones, some fluvial sand stones, phosphorites, chalk, some carbonates, some glacial deposits, bauxite, lignite, some coals, uranium bearing granites and pegmatites, metamorphic rocks of granitic composition, felsic and alkalicvolcanoclastic and pyroclastic volcanic rocks, syenites and carbonatites and many sheared or faulted rocks. The most common sources of uranium and radium are heavy minerals and iron-oxide coatings on rocks and soil grains and in organic materials in soils and sediments. Less common sources are phosphate and carbonate complexes and uranium minerals [2].

There exists a number of factors which are responsible for higher concentrations of radon within buildings including: (1) geological locations; (2) climate and weather effects; (3) building materials; (4) structure, texture and permeability of soil; and (5) occupancy factors within these buildings.

Geological location is an important parameter, responsible for high-radon levels within dwellings. Generally, high levels of radon concentrations are associated with an area where the geology is dominated by granite intrusions.

The 8th October 2005 Kashmir earthquake occurred in the Indus Kohistan Seismic Zone (IKSZ) with its epicentre in the Neelum valley. The event was accompanied by rupture of the Balakot-Bagh fault along the Jhelum river near southeast of Muzafarrabad and further northeast near the town of Balakot in the northwest frontier province of Pakistan [20]. Earthquake has reactivated the fault lines and produced crevice and cracks which have provided the pathways for the migration of radon originating in the bedrock.

This paper is a continuation of our previous studies [21–34] in connection with mapping of Azad Kashmir for potential radon hazards. For this purpose, indoor radon concentrations have been measured in Neelum Valley of Azad Kashmir. We have divided Neelum district into six units (regions), while taking in account lithologies of these regions.

sec.title: Area of Study
sec.p: Neelum Valley is situated in the North and North-East of Muzaffarabad, the capital of the state of Azad Kashmir. Running through the lesser Himalaya, Neelum valley is 144 km long bow-shaped region with mountainous rugged topography. Three main places in Neelum valley are: (1) Athmuqam, (2) Sharda and (3) Kel.

Athmuqam is the sub-divisional headquarters of the area. It is situated at a height of 1371 m, whilst Sharda, – a lush green part of the valley is situated at an altitude of 1981 m. Kel is a small valley situated at a height of 2097 m. Climate is sub-humid with most of the precipitation taking place in winter. The higher reaches receive heavy rainfall. Land forms are mainly fluvial [35,36]. Figure 1 shows photos and basic architectural schemes of the type of houses investigated in the course of this study. Fig. 1.
(a, b, d) Complete mud houses, (c) houses with mud walls and steel roofs, (e) concrete walls with steel roofs and (f) concrete floor, walls and roof.

sec.title: Selection of Sampling Sites
sec.p: About 210 houses were carefully selected from the entire Neelum Valley District to conduct indoor radon survey. The selection of houses was based on geological spread and its location within the studied area. CR-39 detectors were installed in bedroom and living rooms of each house. The selected sites included: Jura, Bandi, Chham, Leswa, Phalakan, Mirpur (situated within geological formation of Jura granite gneiss); Dadrat, Sandok, Sarsangar, Nagan, Bishriai, Ganja, Mianwach, Keran, Neelam (situated within geological formation of Neelum granite); Loharnakka, Patina, Kundalshahi, Rampur, Mangaldhar, Nari, Danna, Kutan-Gali, Nagdarra, Nilam, Nagdarr (situated within geological formation of Kundalshahi); Bugina, Shahkot, Salkha, Authmuqam (situated within geological formation of Authmuqam); Dakhanko, Kandri, Bankhorwali, Changan, Chhanj, Tejian, Mandkaro, Dusut, Khoja, Malakseri, Bharat, Shhari, Jhamran, Surgun, Arangkei (Sharda formation); Sukka Kas, Malkal, Kinari, Kanda Baikh, Kel, Baral (Kel granite gneiss).

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: In this investigation, the passive-integrated technique of Solid State Nuclear Track Detectors (SSNTD) was used to measure indoor radon concentrations. SSNTDs are the most reliable and convenient detectors for the long-term measurement of radon in the environment. These detectors have the advantage to remain unaffected by humidity, temperature effects, moderate heating, light and are low cost. In this regard, CR-39 track detector which mainly detects the alpha particles was used for monitoring of the indoor radon concentrations in the dwellings of the Neelum Valley District.

In order to carry out this study, large sheets of CR-39 detectors having a thickness of 500 µm supplied by the Page Mouldings, Ltd., UK were cut into small strips having dimensions 2 × 2 cm2. Some of the detectors were kept in the refrigerator for background correction purposes. The remaining detectors were then placed in dosimeters of the National Radiological Protection Board (UK) type. The design of the NRPB (now called as Health Protection Agency (HPA) Services) dosimeters ensures that all aerosols and radon decay products are kept outside and only radon could diffuse into the responsive volume of the dosimeter. These dosimeters were calibrated at NRPB and a corresponding calibration factor 2.7 tracks cm−2·h−1 per kBq·m−3 was used.

Detectors were then installed at head heights (i.e. about 1.5 m from the ground) in the bedrooms and living rooms of 210 selected houses of the Neelum Valley District. After 3 months of exposure to the indoor radon, the retrieved CR-39 detectors were etched in 6 M NaOH at 80°C for 16 h. After counting under an optical microscope at 400× magnifications, track densities were corrected for background and then related to the radon concentrations using a calibration factor 2.7 tracks cm−2·h−1 per kBq·m−3. The annual effective dose from measured radon levels was calculated following UNSCEAR Publication (UNSCEAR, 2000) [37].

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The weighted average radon concentration per house was calculated by using Equation (1): (1)WeightedAv.RadonConc =0.45×RadonConc.indrawingroom+0.55 ×RadonConc.inbedroom
The factors (0.45 and 0.55) were determined on the basis of interviews conducted with the house occupiers about probable time spent by them in bedrooms and living rooms per day.

For Jura granite gneiss region, the average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼43 ± 11 to 207 ± 5 Bq·m−3. Arithmetic mean, geometric mean (GM) and geometric standard deviation (GSD) for indoor radon concentrations of all surveyed houses in this region were found as 112 ± 7 Bq·m−3, 105 ± 7 Bq·m−3 and 1.23, respectively. Minimum radon concentration is reported for a house situated in Makwala Bela area, whilst maximum value is reported for a house located in Jura.

Likewise, for Neelum Granite region, the average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼39 ± 12 to 429 ± 4 Bq·m−3. Arithmetic mean, GM and GSD for indoor radon concentrations of all surveyed houses in this region were found as 151 ± 6 Bq·m−3, 131 ± 7 Bq·m−3 and 1.41, respectively. Similarly, for Kundalshahi region, average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼73 ± 9 to 352 ± 4 Bq·m−3. Arithmetic mean, GM and GSD for indoor radon concentrations of all surveyed houses in this region were found as 145 ± 6 Bq·m−3, 135 ± 6 Bq·m−3 and 129, respectively.

For Authmuqam region, average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼50 ± 10 to 304 ± 4 Bq·m−3. Arithmetic mean, GM and GSD for indoor radon concentrations of all surveyed houses in this region were found as 132 ± 6 Bq·m−3, 119 ± 7 Bq·m−3 and 1.30, respectively.

For Sharda formation, average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼29 ± 12 to 324 ± 4 Bq·m−3. Arithmetic mean, GM and GSD for indoor radon concentrations of all surveyed houses in this region were found as 146 ± 5 Bq·m−3, 134 ± 6 Bq·m−3 and 1.44, respectively, whilst for Kel granite gneiss region average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼46 ± 10 to 211 ± 4 Bq·m−3. Arithmetic mean, GM and GSD for indoor radon concentrations of all surveyed houses in this region were found as 119 ± 6 Bq·m−3, 109 ± 6 Bq·m−3 and 1.30, respectively. Overall average value for the studied area was found as 134 ± 7 Bq·m−3.

sec.title: Annual Effective Dose
sec.p: Annual effective dose, H (mSv·y−1) received by the dwellers of the studied area due to the indoor radon and its progeny exposure was calculated from Equation (2) of UNSCEAR 2000 model [37]. (2)H=C(radonconc.)×F(EECfactor) ×O(occpancyfactor)×T(time)×D(DCF) where C stands for weighted average indoor radon concentration in Bq·m−3, F (0.4, taken for indoor inhabitants) for equilibrium equivalent concentration (EEC) factor, O for occupancy factor (0.8 as taken from UNSCEAR 2000 report), T for time (8760 h·y−1) and D for dose conversion factor (DCF) (9 mSv·h−1 per Bq·m−3).

Annual effective doses due to the indoor radon exposure ranged from 1.09 ± 0.29 to 5.23 ± 0.13 mSv·y−1, 0.98 ± 0.3 to 10.82 ± 0.09 mSv·y−1, 1.85 ± 0.22 to 8.88 ± 0.1 mSv·y−1, 1.27 ± 0.25 to 7.67 ± 0.1 mSv·y−1, 0.74 ± 0.3 to 8.18 ± 0.09 mSv·y−1 and 1.16 ± 0.24 to 5.32 ± 0.11 mSv·y−1 for Jura granite gneiss region, Neelum Granite region, Kundalshahi region, Authmuqam region, Sharda formation and Kel granite gneiss region, respectively (Table 2). For the entire district, the annual effective doses varied from 0.74 ± 0.3 mSv·y−1 for Sharda formation to 10.82 ± 0.09 mSv·y−1 for Neelum Granite region.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Variations observed in indoor radon concentrations can be seen from the frequency distribution graph as shown in Figure 2. Fig. 2.
Frequency distribution of indoor radon concentration in Neelum Valley.

The shape of the graph follows lognormal distribution. In order to find geometrical spread of data, arithmetic mean, GM and GSD have been calculated. The GM and GSD portray lognormal distribution, whilst the arithmetic mean estimates the average probability of detrimental health effects associated with indoor radon data of the surveyed region.

Figure 3 shows the lognormal probability graph of radon concentrations in six regions of Neelum Valley. The data of all six measurements fit the lognormal distribution well. For any lognormal distribution, we can calculate GM and GSD values. Calculated GM and GSD values for six regions of surveyed area were used to calculate proportion of houses with indoor radon concentrations higher than the guideline value given by the Health Protection Agency, UK (200 Bq·m−3). It is found that 14.72% houses have an elevated indoor radon concentration. About 3.8% of the houses had radon concentrations in the ranges 0–50 Bq·m−3; 24.28%, 51–100 Bq·m−3; 38.57%, 101–150 Bq·m−3; 18.57%, 151–200 Bq·m−3; 9%, 201–250 Bq·m−3; 3.33%, 251–300 Bq·m−3; 0.95%, 301–350 Bq·m−3; 0.95%, 351–400 Bq·m−3; 0.5% 401–450 Bq·m−3. Fig. 3.
Lognormal probability graph of radon concentration in six regions of Neelum.

Higher indoor radon concentrations have been observed in dwellings of the Neelum Granite region. This region is exposed to granite which is hypidiomorphic subprophyritic and non-gneissic. Ghazanfar et al. [36] reported the percentage of minerals found in rocks of this area as: microcline-perthite (20–28%), muscovite (5–10%), biotite (1–12%), sericite (1–2%), garnet (4%, only in single sample), silliminite (1–4%). The granite found in this region is a medium grained, porphyritic, two mica post-kinematic intrusions. Along with some joint faces, black radiating aggregates of tourmaline are also found in this area.

In Kundalshahi formation, two different lithologies are found: (1) garnetiferous quartzites and garnetiferous quartzitic schists, (2) garnet mica schists. The petrographic study of the region indicates that the original lithology could be of shales [36]. Authmuqam region has a deceptive field appearance. Rocks could look like sedimentary. The Sharda formation is composed of two types of lithologies: (1) garnet mica schists and gneisses; (2) calcareous quartz mica gneisses. The petrography indicates an original composition varying from calcarious pelites to argillaceous carbonates with an occasional sandstone band. In Kel region, rocks found are gneissic, subprophyritic. Pregranitisation metamorphic relies of garnet-muscovite-biotite (+quartz) are also present [36].

Neelum valley was the epicenter of 2005 Kashmir earthquake, due to this reason many cracks and fissures along with huge land slide and road ruptures were produced in different parts of the area. The level of damage in Kel and Sharda region was comparably small with the regions of Jura, Neelum granite and Kundalshahi regions. Many houses investigated in these areas have cracks in their floors with no cemented prevention. This may be the cause of elevated indoor radon concentrations found in these areas compared to regions of Authmuqam, Kel and Sharda.

sec.title: Analytical Strategy
sec.p: The Kruskal-Wallis one-way analysis of variance was used for testing the equality of medians of the data obtained for the six regions of the Neelum district. The Kruskal-Wallis test is well suited to measure the degree to which various sums of ranks differ [38]. Radon concentration was positively related (p = 0.061) to the lithology of studied area within the confidence level of 10%. Granite intrusion area seems to be more prone to radon health hazards compared to sedimentary or metamorphic rocks exposed area.

sec.title: Comparison of Survey Results
sec.p: Since there is no locally adopted criterion for upper level (health threatening) of indoor radon concentration in Pakistan, the comparisons here of the current survey results with World Health Organisation (WHO) (100 Bq·m−3), US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) (148 Bq·m−3) and Health Protection Agency, UK (200 Bq·m−3) have been made [26]. A comparison of current survey results with WHO guideline value suggests that only 28% surveyed houses are within the safe limit, on the other hand, 72% houses have elevated radon concentrations higher than the recommended value given by WHO [39]. Comparing with the US EPA (148 Bq·m−3) recommendation, 66.7% of houses have indoor radon concentration below the criterion and only 33.3% of houses have elevated radon concentrations. When comparing with the recommendation given by the Health Protection Agency of the UK (200 Bq·m−3), 85.28% of surveyed houses are within safe limit and only 14.72% houses have elevated indoor radon concentrations.

The comparisons of average weighted radon concentrations, 112 ± 7 Bq·m−3, 151 ± 6 Bq·m−3, 145 ± 6 Bq·m−3, 132 ± 6 Bq·m−3, 146 ± 5 Bq·m−3 and 119 ± 6 Bq·m−3 found in Jura granite gneiss, Neelum Granite, Kundalshahi, Authmuqam, Sharda formation and Kel granite gneiss regions; with WHO, US EPA and Health Protection Agency UK are shown in Figure 4. The weighted average radon concentrations exceeding the WHO guideline value were well below the standard set by Health Protection Agency of the UK. Fig. 4.
Comparison of indoor radon concentrations of the surveyed areas with WHO, US EPA and UK Health Protection Agency Guideline values.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The following conclusions are drawn from the current survey:
Average indoor radon concentration varied from ∼29 ± 12 Bq·m−3 to 429 ± 4 Bq·m−3 for the houses of the Neelum district.
Overall mean value for indoor radon concentration was found as 138 ± 7 Bq·m−3.
Mean annual effective doses due to the indoor radon exposure ranged from 0.74 ± 0.3 to 10.82 ± 0.09 mSv·y−1.
The minimum dose due to the indoor radon (0.74 ± 0.3 mSv·y−1) was noted in Bankhorwali region situated in Sharda formation whilst the maximum value of the dose (10.82 ± 0.09 mSv·y−1) was found in the Sandok area situated in Neelum granite region.
Overall mean effective dose for the studied area was found as 3.49 ± 0.14 mSv·y−1.
About 72% of surveyed houses have radon concentrations greater than the guideline value given by WHO (100 Bq·m−3). Comparing with the US EPA’s guideline value of 148 Bq·m−3, 33.3% of houses have radon concentrations greater than the criterion; whilst 14.72% houses have an elevated indoor radon concentration, which is higher than the guideline value given by the Health Protection Agency, UK (200 Bq·m−3).
